properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected today. Total Snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time Span: this morning until this evening. Remarks: The heaviest snow is expected this morning and afternoon before tapering to flurries later in the afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-20T00:49:03-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected tonight into Sunday. Total Snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Locations: southeastern New Brunswick. Time Span: overnight tonight to Sunday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin tonight in the west and spread eastward. The heaviest snow is expected Sunday morning and afternoon before dissipating Sunday night as the storm moves eastward. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected tonight into Sunday. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: southwestern New Brunswick. Time span: late this evening into Sunday. Remarks: Snow will develop late this evening in the west then spread eastwards. Snow is expected to taper to flurries Sunday afternoon. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are currently forecast, but there is the possibility some areas may reach warning criteria of 15 or more cm. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T18:34:01-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow over the weekend... A low pressure system tracking across Southern Quebec is expected to generate 10 to 15 centimetres of snow by Sunday afternoon. Moderate to occasionally strong east winds will also cause local blowing snow, especially in exposed areas near the St. Lawrence and Ottawa valleys. The accumulating snow, reduced visibilities and low temperatures should cause road conditions to deteriorate and make travel difficult. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T18:59:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-19T03:54:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3186680643.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected tonight into Sunday. Snow squalls are expected to develop tonight as cold northwesterly winds develop over Lake Huron. The snow squalls are then forecast to continue through the early part of Sunday before weakening and moving south of the area late Sunday afternoon. The strong northwest winds gusting up to 60 or 70 km/h will also result in localized blowing snow with the snow squalls. Total snowfall amounts up to 20 cm are possible by Sunday evening. The highest amounts are expected along the Lake Huron shoreline from Kincardine and south towards Grand Bend. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T18:39:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-19T02:40:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0656984877.2020

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain extending along the highways east of Hope. A strong storm system has brought mixed precipitation to the Fraser Valley. Warm air aloft pushes inland tonight and freezing rain is expected for portions of the Coquihalla and the Hope Princeton Highways, near Hope. Freezing rain will extend further inland Sunday morning then transition to rain showers late Sunday morning on the Coquihalla and around noon on the Hope Princeton Highway. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T21:54:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-19T06:20:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1879022577.2020

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight into early Sunday morning. Snow squalls have developed over Lake Huron late tonight. The most intense snow squall is currently moving inland near Point Clark but is forecast to shift southward through the night towards the Goderich and Exeter areas. Heavy bursts of snow and significantly reduced visibilities at times can be expected through tonight. Motorists are advised to exercise caution and be prepared for quickly changing driving conditions. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

Northerly winds gusting up to 50 km/h are expected to develop tonight and will create areas of blowing snow giving reduced visibilities at times. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More snow on the way to start the week. Total snowfall: generally 10 to 15 cm with locally higher amounts possible in areas of heavier snow. Locations: All of Newfoundland except the Northern Peninsula and West Coast. Time Frame: Sunday night and Monday morning. Remarks. There is some uncertainty as to how far west the low generating this snowfall will track as it crosses either central or eastern Newfoundland. Southeastern areas of the Island including the Burin and Avalon Peninsulas will see a brief changeover to rain or drizzle overnight Sunday night into Monday before the precipitation ends. Strong east to southeasterly winds will accompany the snow to give reduced visibilities in blowing snow Sunday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-19T18:08:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-19T02:09:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3822897444.2020

properties.Summary:

Additionally, cold arctic air is expected to make a return to the region tonight allowing lake effect flurries to develop and persist through Sunday. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold values of -40 to -45 continue tonight into Sunday morning. Temperatures will moderate from Sunday into Monday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong Pacific storm has arrived with a mix of wintery weather including heavy snow and freezing rain. The freezing rain over northern sections of Squamish will change to rain near midnight. Snow will continue to fall over northern sections of the Sea to Sky with amounts up to 20 cm expected. The snow will change over to freezing rain late Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T17:59:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-19T06:57:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2874413906.2020
Area: Sea to Sky - Squamish to Whistler
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow today. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50-70 km/h. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: today and this evening. Remarks: Snow over the Island will intensify later this morning and taper off to flurries late this evening. Strong easterly winds in the afternoon then northerly winds in the evening will reduce visibility at times in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-20T00:52:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-19T08:53:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3948594833.2020
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 45 and minus 50. Extreme wind chill values continue tonight into Sunday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T20:14:05-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain will develop overnight near Chilliwack and Hope. The freezing rain will change to rain early Sunday morning near Chilliwack and early Sunday afternoon near Hope. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall today Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm, with up to 30 over parts of Victoria County. Maximum wind gusts: 50-70 km/h. Locations: central, northern, and eastern Nova Scotia Time span: today and this evening Remarks: Snow will spread from mainland Nova Scotia to Cape Breton early this morning. Parts of the Atlantic coast will likely see a switch over to rain this afternoon and evening while areas further inland are expected to remain as snow. The heaviest snow is expected this morning and afternoon before tapering to flurries this evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-20T00:51:44-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong Pacific storm has arrived with a mix of wintery weather including heavy snow and freezing rain. The freezing rain over northern sections of Squamish will change to rain near midnight. Snow will continue to fall over northern sections of the Sea to Sky with amounts up to 20 cm expected. The snow will change over to freezing rain late Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-19T17:59:57-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will continue to bring snow to the Whistler region tonight and Sunday morning. An additional 10 to 15 cm of snow is expected tonight. The snow will become mixed with freezing rain Sunday afternoon and will change to rain Sunday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
